150414942.review:
Banished is a fun city builder with a survival approach that can be pretty unforgiving when you don't know what you are doing, which will ultimately lead to the unstoppable death of your whole village. Your population will suffer from sickness, overaging, food and firewood shortages, work accidents and certain other problems that can be quite hard to manage. Your workers need to build homes and other necessities, plow the field, catch some fish and exploit the natural ressources that are required to make their lives more livable and safer. 

After a certain amount of failed attempts, you surely will get the hang of it and seeing your small peasant village turn into an educated bigger city full of schools, hospitals and markets will give you a satisfying feeling. Building a civilization surely ain't an easy thing! The visuals are quite charming and i liked the smaller details here and there while the soundtrack in the background is calming your senses. Available mods can add more depth to the title and also a bigger variety in buldings, which is nice for replayability.

Due to the rather low price, you can basically do nothing wrong when you decide to get it. A true pleasure for every fan of the city building genre, which comes with a certain oldschool feeling. The developer, only 1 person by the way, did a top notch job.

Have fun!

All in all I highly recommend this game because even though it's a bit older it has aged like a fine wine.

In short: For $20 I think its the right price for a relaxed experience. 

I figured after getting every achievement i would write a review. i play a lot of survival, city builder, etc. Banished is in its own little side category. Its a very relaxing builder with a few basic things to sort out. There isn't a tech tree, there isn't a story line, no enemies but I have always viewed it as starting a frontier town in wild west.

Its relaxing to play as there isn't any insane factors to contend with. You try new generated maps and try to get enough food and warmth for Winter. That said its also not a game that you can let run and walk away from for 10-20 minutes. The mistakes you make wont be realized until well into the future. Which is fun if you like that planning aspect and a snowball build up of failure. 

If you want a hard challenge then look elsewhere. If you want something that's fun/relaxed and enjoy planning a ideal frontier town, then this is the game

You can set up a village the same twice, same buildings, number of people, workers, and come out with one village dying of starvation, and one village living. A city that is thriving, without a population increase, will hit a "food wall" and no matter the population decrease, will never recover because the food will remain at critical levels. This can happen to all resources for no reasons explained through events. Because of the broken mechanics, what would be an absolute gem of a game, is a nightmare to play.

149912061.review:
This game could perhaps be titled "Banished by the Learning Curve", because whew is it a steep one. That said, this back-to-basics RTS/city-builder is actually pretty solid, and presents a good challenge to all players. The graphics aren't anything spectacular, and the gameplay is relatively mundane, but the difficulty of managing and maintaining the settlement will definitely have you looking past the overall mediocrity because you will be heavily focused on micromanagement of shovels and food stuffs. Once you have a grip on the basic build up, the game doesn't let you slack off either, introducing numerous additional challenges that will test your management skills and the resilience of your community.
Banished probably isn't a game for a casual "I want to sit back and relax" type evening, but one that a dedicated management type gamer will enjoy.

149259483.review:
I'm recommending this game only if we're judging it as a game that came out in 2014. In that sense, it will give you enough to do for 4-6-10 hours, if you're OCD about struggling to balance the resources of a colony destined to die anyway.

After 13 hours of playing, I somehow managed to grow my town to a population of 1,634 people { 1,404 adults, 116 students and 114 children }. Only 47% of them are educated, which might explain why I've cluttered  several cemeteries with dumb stonecutters crushed by rocks...

I feel like everything I like about the game eventually I end up hating:
- I like the simplicity of it, but then I wish there were more buildings/occupations for my villagers to work in. At the moment I have about 100 laborers who just carry stuff and clean up areas where I am trying to expand. 

- I like the fact that there's a bunch of fruits and veggies that my farmers can cultivate, yet aside from the fruits and wheat used on alcohol, I have no idea how the rest of them influence my colony. I wish we had an indicator for how much each type of produce influences the quality of my villagers' lives.

- I like the fact that I can play forever (I am currently on year 88), but I feel like it's a drag to get to the 100 and 200 years milestones necessary for two of the achievements. This is a horrible way to pad the gameplay time in order to keep people playing if they're achievements completionists.

- I like the fact that I can herd sheep, cows and chickens, but this is a medieval colony management game... where's the pigs?! Give us horses and carts so that people can travel faster and carry more goods.

- I like the overall look and atmosphere of the medieval village, but I wish we had more than just churches and taverns to entertain the community. I am aware that you can mod the game, but I won't bother with it since there's no long-term goal of the game.

- I like the fact that the seasons change and that impacts food production, but if you have a few hundred people, you will burn through your veggies and meats super fast. I wish we had bears and boars and other wildlife to give more meat than deer do.

What I clearly don't like:
- Having no clear indicators of how much food each farm/orchard/fishing dock/hunter/pasture gives, I feel like stocking on food is a guessing game. 

- After the 50 years mark, I feel like my population gets hit by calamities too often. 

- Stonecutters and miners die way too often in work-related accidents. I'm surprised hunters don't die in accidents or fishermen don't drown.

- We have corn and wheat, but no mills and bakeries to produce bread or cornbread.

- No vineyards. Also, no difference in what you use to make alcohol (you have stuff like what, berries, cherries, plums, peaches, etc, but what's really the point?). I wish we had wine, not just ales.

- Traders still bring seeds to sell, even after you've unlocked all types available in game. Sometimes this is super annoying, as you will rely on trade to balance your resources intake/outtake.

 - Quarries are horrible. Once you've depleted the stone in them, you're left with giant craters that render the land plot useless. I have 8 of those and they look depressing. My village is beginning to look like a Moon colony with all the craters.
Same issue with mines.

- Since we have mines, I wish we could extract gold or silver and mint coins. Makes more sense in trading than being at the mercy of however much of a specific resource each random traders wants in exchange for their goods.

- My idiot villagers pop out children like crazy. It's cool that they'll replace everyone who will die of old age, but I feel like I'm a race to build more housing than anything else. Then build farms to feed them, then hope nothing wrong happens with the crops or farmers, so that I can actually collect the food they so rapidly deplete.


So yeah, fun game if you like to torture yourself. Bring a pencil and paper, because you'll be pausing a lot to do guess-work math about food management.

149253214.review:
Banished is not just a city builder; it's a story of survival, strategy, and endless possibilities. In this charmingly challenging game, you're tasked with guiding a group of outcasts to build a thriving settlement in a harsh, unforgiving world.

The complexity of Banished is evident from the get-go. The early game is where all the challenges lie. Building and sustaining your first community feels monumental as you juggle limited resources and a growing population.

It's a game that requires careful planning, balancing resources, and managing your ever-expanding village. One misstep can lead to a domino effect of "death crosses," suddenly, your thriving community is on the brink of extinction.

The beauty of Banished is that it has stood the test of time, maintaining its charm and relevance even a decade later. With the addition of mods, the game's potential soars to new heights. Want a high-maintenance aquarium? There's a mod for that!

While some may find Banished to have a steep learning curve, the satisfaction of mastering its intricacies makes it worth every moment. It's a game perfect for those looking for a challenging yet peaceful colony sim, especially if you're a fan of casual colony survival without the interference of critters or aliens.

Whether you're a seasoned player or new to the genre, Banished has something to offer. The sense of accomplishment that comes from turning a struggling settlement into a thriving community is what makes this game truly exceptional.

148016758.review:
"Banished" is a remarkable city-building simulation game that offers a refreshing take on the genre. Developed by a single indie developer, Luke Hodorowicz, it's a testament to the fact that great things can come from small studios. Let's delve into what makes "Banished" a compelling experience.
Pros:

Challenging Gameplay: "Banished" presents a considerable challenge in terms of resource management and survival. The game doesn't hold your hand, making it deeply satisfying when your town flourishes.

Simplicity and Depth: Despite its simplicity in design, "Banished" offers deep gameplay mechanics. It's easy to grasp the basics, but mastering them is a rewarding journey.

Beautiful Aesthetic: The game's visuals are striking, with a rustic, medieval charm that immerses you in the world. The changing seasons and attention to detail add to the visual appeal.

Societal Dynamics: The game explores societal dynamics as your population grows and ages. Managing citizens' needs and desires adds depth to the gameplay.

Modding Community: "Banished" boasts a dedicated modding community, offering an extensive library of mods that enhance gameplay, graphics, and overall content.

Cons:

Steep Learning Curve: The game's learning curve can be quite steep, and newcomers might find themselves struggling initially. However, this can also be seen as a pro for players who enjoy a challenge.

Lack of Story or Campaign: "Banished" is more of a sandbox experience. It lacks a structured story or campaign mode, which may disappoint players looking for a more guided experience.

Repetitive Late Game: In the late game, gameplay can become somewhat repetitive as you've already established a well-functioning town. It could benefit from more late-game content or objectives.

In summary, "Banished" is a hidden gem in the city-building genre. Its blend of simplicity, depth, and challenge, coupled with its gorgeous aesthetics, make it an excellent choice for players who enjoy strategy and management games. While it has a steep learning curve and lacks a structured narrative, the satisfaction of watching your town thrive is well worth the investment. The vibrant modding community ensures that the game's replayability remains high.

"Banished" es un juego de simulación de construcción de ciudades excepcional que ofrece un enfoque refrescante en el género. Desarrollado por un único creador independiente, Luke Hodorowicz, es un testimonio de que las grandes creaciones pueden provenir de pequeños estudios. Vamos a analizar qué hace que "Banished" sea una experiencia atractiva.

Pros:

Jugabilidad Desafiante: "Banished" presenta un gran desafío en términos de gestión de recursos y supervivencia. El juego no te lleva de la mano, lo que lo hace profundamente satisfactorio cuando tu ciudad prospera.

Simplicidad y Profundidad: A pesar de su diseño simple, "Banished" ofrece mecánicas de juego profundas. Es fácil comprender los conceptos básicos, pero dominarlos es un viaje gratificante.

Estética Hermosa: Los visuales del juego son impresionantes, con un encanto rústico y medieval que te sumerge en el mundo. Las estaciones cambiantes y la atención al detalle añaden atractivo visual.

Dinámicas Sociales: El juego explora las dinámicas sociales a medida que crece y envejece tu población. Gestionar las necesidades y deseos de los ciudadanos agrega profundidad al juego.

Comunidad de Mods: "Banished" cuenta con una dedicada comunidad de modders que ofrecen una extensa biblioteca de mods que mejoran la jugabilidad, los gráficos y el contenido en general.

Contras:

Curva de Aprendizaje Pronunciada: La curva de aprendizaje del juego puede ser bastante pronunciada, y los recién llegados pueden encontrarse luchando inicialmente. Sin embargo, esto también puede ser visto como un punto positivo para los jugadores que disfrutan de un desafío.

Falta de Historia o Campaña: "Banished" es más una experiencia de sandbox. Carece de una historia estructurada o un modo campaña, lo que puede decepcionar a los jugadores que buscan una experiencia más guiada.

Repetitividad en la Parte Tardía: En la etapa final del juego, la jugabilidad puede volverse algo repetitiva, ya que has establecido una ciudad que funciona bien. Podría beneficiarse de más contenido o objetivos en la parte tardía del juego.

En resumen, "Banished" es una joya escondida en el género de construcción de ciudades. Su combinación de simplicidad, profundidad y desafío, junto con su estética magnífica, lo convierten en una excelente elección para los jugadores que disfrutan de juegos de estrategia y gestión. Aunque tiene una curva de aprendizaje pronunciada y carece de una narrativa estructurada, la satisfacción de ver prosperar tu ciudad vale la inversión. La vibrante comunidad de modders asegura que la capacidad de rejugabilidad del juego se mantenga alta.

146738701.review:
Long review alert.

Great game. I'd like to see a mash-up between my favourite parts from this and Rimworld made into a new game.
Being as I've only been playing for 23 hours I'm sure there will be a few more things I'll uncover. So far...

Plus:
Real world scenario.  (No sci-fi, no zombies, no post apocalypse situations etc.)
Nice use of geography as a limitation device. The rivers, especially, force interesting choices.
Merciful saving, pausing and difficulty mode systems.
Robust modding community.

Minus:
Characters mean next to nothing unless you get attached to a name for some reason.
Villagers have unrealistic restrictions. (only so many can work per farm even at crunch time during harvest season etc...)
Villagers have no sense of conditional urgency. (Multiple times I've watched one finally arrive from town, having done God knows what, only to stop just short of helping with harvesting a crop because they needed to go back to town to eat food!?!?!?)

These minuses don't ruin the game but they do make me wish some things were a little different.

Ideally I'd like to see a system of random events (not natural disasters.) Things like unusual wildlife encounters, non-violent non-villager people encounters, differences developing within the village that must be negotiated to avoid people leaving, discoveries of abandoned villages, abandoned mines, there are a lot of possibilities that would add some immersive qualities to the game.

It would be nice to have more environmental variety. ( I know there are mods that I must check out.) More character in the rivers and lakes, caves, waterfalls, swampland, ravines, arches, tar pits, hot springs, etc...

There's probably already a thousand miles worth of code involved in this game and it's already a great game but I'm always looking for some specific gaming experiences and I thought I'd share a bit.

Still, I haven't put it down so I can't say this was a bad purchase, heh.

145875843.review:
The game that put survival city builders as a genre on the map. The game start is very hard (always save the moment you start a game because you might need a couple of tries to survive the first couple of winters. The early game is all about juggling limited citizens with resource and goods development. Not growing faster than your food supplies, etc. And gradually it gets easier in the mid-game, which is where a lot of reviewers say it gets too easy. But if you keep playing into the late game you can actually run out of map and be in a delicate balance of maintaining your population without growing because you're at your production limits. Trade becomes vitally important. It's a whole new kind of challenge.

I love this game. I've gotten all the achievements (which is mainly being persistent). It has a good balance of enough resources to be interesting without so many that they're hard to track (and if you want more there are a bunch of mods that add things or even reimagine the game). I enjoy the challenge and the spinning plates. It's an excellent companion to a  podcast or a TTRPG show.

The graphics are pretty. I enjoy watching all the little people go about their jobs, and I enjoy the sound design. I also love that this game is basically a communist society working together to all mutually benefit, and it really set the tone for survival city builders in that regard, too. I always like seeing the story game mechanics tell in city builders. Like disease spread discouraging monocultures.

I've played hundreds and hundreds of hours of this game and I'll play hundreds more. I've only recently started experimenting with the mods that can really transform the gameplay even further.

145815463.review:
I have a couple of tips. 
Sustainable food such as fishing is key. Fishing is done regardless of season. 
Herds are the second most important food source.
Farms are LUXURIES. Whether its a tree farm or farm farm they are luxuries. I find that they are far too often an unreliable food source.
Once you start building or upgrading to stone houses never build another wood house ever. The population boom is not worth the food/fuel ratio. 
Never neglect having a teacher. Having educated population is always worth the 1 person.
1 blacksmith and 1 tailor are good for 200 people.
I often have "outposts" of the 4 starting essentials. Forester. Gathering Hut, Hunting cabin, Herbalist. Put these 4 buildings together and they will provide a great asset.

144758034.review:
Banished é um jogo único no plano de City Builders. É um jogo lento, metódico, em que você tem que pensar bem antes de fazer qualquer construção ou decisão. Aqui todos os cidadãos da colônia podem fazer qualquer função, mas você escolhe o que cada um vai fazer especificamente, e até coisas como construir uma casa pode levar tempo no começo do jogo. Vou dar alguns exemplos de situações comuns que podem acontecer se você não souber lidar com a gestão de recursos e cadeia produtiva no jogo:

[b]1. [Importância da Madeira][/b] Se você não tiver silvicultores coletando madeira e operários para mover essa madeira para os lenhadores cortarem e transformarem em lenha, que então é levada pelos mercadores ao mercado para que a população geral possa levar para suas casas, todos podem morrer de hipotermia no inverno pela falta de aquecimento.

A questão aqui é que você também precisa da madeira para construir várias coisas no jogo, então você precisa estabelecer um balanço entre a velocidade de expansão e manter os colonos que já estão vivos supridos.

[b]2. [Importância da Comida][/b] Você precisa de comida para que todos sobrevivam, e há várias formas de conseguir comida: agricultura, agropecuária, pescaria, coleta silvestre, etc. Entretanto, cada uma dessas comidas precisam ser coletadas por um cidadão, que então leva para um armazém. 

A cada ano, esses mesmos cidadãos também precisam consumir uma quantidade de comida, então se você tiver pouca produção, pode gerar uma situação em que não há comida suficiente para todos, especialmente se construir casas muito rapidamente, porque os colonos terão filhos e isso aumenta exponencialmente o consumo, especialmente porque as crianças não podem trabalhar até ficarem mais velhas.

[b]3. [Efetividade dos Colonos][/b] Escolas, ferramentas e roupas de frio fazem com que os colonos trabalhem de forma mais efetiva (cerca de dobro de efetividade acumulada), mas cada uma delas vem com desvantagens. Escolas fazem com que as novas crianças, que geralmente poderiam trabalhar desde os 10 anos, só comecem a trabalhar por volta dos 18-21, atrasando o desenvolvimento imediato da colônia para priorizar eficiência futura. Ferramentas e roupas precisam de colonos específicos trabalhando em toda linha de produção delas. Ferreiro, operários, mineradores e mercadores são algumas pra ferramentas, por exemplo. 

Dois grandes problemas podem surgir aqui. O primeiro é você estabelecer uma economia saudável usando ferramentas e colonos educados, mas não planejar escolas ou a linha de produção de ferramentas conforme a colônia cresça. Isso faz com que falte ferramentas e a produção diminua drasticamente, afetando todas as outras cadeias produtivas, desde a madeira para aquecimento até a produção de alimento. A colônia então entra em colapso e muitas mortes acontecem. 

O segundo problema é você estabelecer uma colônia tão eficiente que os produtos começam a ser feitos em quantidades astronômicas sem limite, o que enche os armazéns de ferramentas e roupas que não serão utilizadas tão cedo e diminui o espaço para alimentos que seriam vitais. A solução pra isso seria simples: vender com um comerciante estrangeiro que vem de barco.

---------

Escrevi tudo isso pra mostrar como esse jogo não é fácil, especialmente no começo. Suas primeiras colônias irão fracassar, e isso é um fato. Quando você entende as dinâmicas do jogo, entretanto, ele fica muito mais gostoso e simples de jogar, porque não é um jogo com infinitas mecânicas. Existem mods que aumentam as cadeias de produção pra quantidades absurdas se essa for sua parte favorita do jogo, e elas deixam o jogo ter uma replayabilidade insana, então pelo preço esse jogo é incrivelmente barato pela quantidade de horas que você consegue jogar e aproveitar. 

Não há nada como Banished no mercado. O mais próximo que consigo imaginar - sem ser o jogo [u][url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/1538570/Patron/]Patron[/url][/u], seu clone moderno - é [u][url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/40950/Stronghold_HD/]Stronghold[/url][/u], mas sem os elementos de combate e com micromanagement de profissões.

[b]Nota: 8/10 - MUITO BOM[/b]

143555418.review:
Banished: A Meticulous Balance of Survival and Creativity - An In-depth Review

Introduction:
Tucked away in the expansive realm of indie games lies a remarkable treasure named Banished. Crafted by Shining Rock Software, this city-building simulator invites players into a world where strategic ingenuity is the beacon of survival. Banished stands out with its mod-friendly architecture, opening a vista of endless in-game possibilities, making it a boundless playground for both the methodical planner and the creative mind.

The Grit and The Glory:
The first brush with Banished unveils a realm where every decision casts a long shadow on your settlement's fate. Nestled amidst unforgiving terrains, the challenge of managing resources, shelter, and the welfare of your citizens quickly unfolds. Yet, as daunting as the challenges may seem, the triumphant feeling of overcoming hurdles and watching your city thrive is intoxicating.

Canvas of Imagination:
Beyond the veil of survival, Banished extends a blank canvas awaiting the strokes of your imagination. A vast landscape lies before you, ready to morph into bustling urban sprawls or serene hamlets based on your vision. The autonomy to design and evolve your town is both liberating and stimulating.

Aesthetic Harmony:
The visual aesthetics in Banished are crafted to immerse. The scenic, pastoral landscapes instill a calm that juxtaposes beautifully against the buzzing activity of your growing settlement. The seamless transition between seasons and varying weather conditions not only enriches the visual charm but weaves an extra layer of realism into the gameplay.

Intricate Dynamics:
Appearances can be deceiving, and Banished is a testament to that. Beneath its simple facade lies a complex matrix of systems and decisions that mold the trajectory of your settlement. The ripple effect of early game choices unveils a level of depth that keeps every playthrough fresh and rewarding.

Modding: A Gateway to Infinity:
The magic of mod compatibility in Banished unveils a realm of endless exploration. A vibrant modding community has rallied around the game, conjuring a plethora of user-generated content. From architectural expansions to gameplay tweaks, the mods extend a path to tailor your Banished experience, adding a robust replay value to the game.

Vibrant Community and Unwavering Support:
An ever-welcoming community surrounds Banished. The developer's sustained engagement and regular game updates have fostered a milieu of support with abundant guides, tutorials, and forums, offering a helping hand to both novices and veterans.

Conclusion:
Banished is more than just a city-building simulator; it's a meticulous blend of survival's grit and the unrestrained liberty of creativity. The game's essence, enhanced by a rich modding landscape, ensures a unique journey every time you delve into its world. Whether a seasoned architect of cities or a newcomer to the genre, Banished has a narrative that will resonate with you. Embrace the realm where your strategic prowess and imaginative capacity are the keys to a thriving civilization. Happy building!

143148932.review:
A resource management game boiled down to its bare essentials... and then boiled a bit longer.

I want to like Banished.  I really do.  I love resource management games.  I can forgive the complete lack of a story.  I can forgive the lack of framing quests and goals.  But what I cannot forgive is bad design.  For a resource management game, it's missing some fairly key things.
Such as:
- a way to see in one place how much of a given resource you're forecast to be producing (they'll tell you how much you have already produced that year, but that doesn't help for things like crops that get harvested all at once.)
- how much your citizens are forecast to consume (again, they will tell you how much they already have, but this ignores the population you are TRYING to grow)
- the ages of all your citizens in one place (people grow old and die and need to have younger people to replace them.  A bar graph showing all the ages of the people would be immensely helpful - something to tell you if you have a rapidly ageing population and be sure you have incoming students/children to replace them)
- A way to look at a farm or an orchard and know how much it will produce that year at 100%.  (Sometimes there's an early frost and you can't get to 100%, but that's ok, that's just part of the challenge)
- Honestly, ANYTHING predictive would be nice.  This game makes me want to set up excel spreadsheets to fill in the lack.  There is no way to know how much food a fishery produces compared to a hunter's cabin, or how much you're cutting into production by overlapping the hunting radii.
- On that note - when placing a building with a radius, show us the radii of other buildings of that type so we can avoid overlap.  Tell us if it's going to produce less than 100% and how much 100% IS.

That's most of my gripes.  Basically, it's a resource management game that doesn't give you all the tools you need to manage your resources.

141959255.review:
This is one of the best Colony games and the best one without combat.

Without combat there is no need to consider balance and with no balance you're free to play how you want.

There are no tech trees or building upgrades 1-2-3 etc, instead if you want to increase the productivity of your workers you need to equip them with tools, give them an education and provide logistically sensible stockpiles and storage areas. You can renovate a wooden house into stone but that's the only upgrade.

Without technology and upgrades it's up to the user to use their own common sense to reduce collateral damage and increase productivity. Space same type agricultural areas apart with alternate types of agriculture to prevent the spread of disease, Space homes and buildings apart to reduce the spread of fire and plague, Plan your logistical network to reduce production times. Make the most of the empty green spaces in your city with foresters and gatherers.

Trade ships will arrive at a trade dock periodically and through them the player can acquire more crop types, animals, produced goods and even stone and iron ore which can all be traded for any item the player colony produces depending on the trade ships preference. 

The biggest obstacle in this game is hubris, over population, over expansion and depleting natural resources without a long term solution in mind. 


10/10 in a Vacuum.
8/10 in The Wild.

You can assign areas for workers to gather timber, stone and iron without a production building.

141691915.review:
steam was having a sale so I looked for a city builder and found that many reviews compared whichever game I was looking at to this one and the reviews looked positive so I decided to get this....thank god I only wasted £5.

The game is almost impossible to play, even after spending hours looking at the how to's online.
First thing you need to do is produce food, logs and sticks......in order to produce enough food you have to ignore the other two, which then means everyone freezes to death. Try to split your time between all 3 and you wont produce enough food, so everyone starves to death.
If by some fluke you manage to survive the first couple of years (usually with only two settlers left) then the next thing will be a fire which cannot be put out, meaning there is no food production so everyone starves. Again I looked online for how to deal with fire, but the labourers just run back and forth over the same 10 squares and don't attempt to put the fire out so the town burns to the ground around them.

In the 11 hours I've played I have started over 20 games and not been able to progress in any of them - labourers decide they can't be bothered to collect food, so everyone starves. Ask labourers to collect wood, stone or iron - everybody starves. Force them to collect food - everybody freezes, even in summer.
Food production takes waay too long, and doesn't produce enough to feed the starting population anyway. The tutorial says to build Fishing Wharf, and yes there is in instant flow of food, but not even close to being enough to feed the population.
Buildings take an age to go up, so each game year you are limited to 2 or 3 if you are lucky. But as you also need to gather the resources for these buildings, your pops are going to starve coz no one is collecting food.

You can't assign specific pops to buildings, you tell it how many to work in the building type and then off they go - labourers on the other hand are completely controlled by the game AI so they do what that wants them to do, rather than what you want them to do...for example, you have 10 labourers, rather than a couple being sent to gather the resources you need and others gathering food, they ALL go to gather resources or they ALL go to gather food - your pops either starve or freeze because the dumb AI cannot let them do more than one thing at a time.

This is one of the most frustrating, pointless games I have ever played - even with mods its no better, it's either freeze or starve every single time.

139651707.review:
I play this game in 7 hour stints, at which point, you reach a developmental ceiling for your settlement. The people that play more then 7 hours are the type that get obsessed and very fixated on beating the hardest difficulty setting via min-maxing all actions. If you love to min-max in a city-builder as if you were a Starcraft player, this game is perfect for you.

On normal mode, I always found the hardest part of the game to be the early game, and once you have the basics balanced, the rest of game is simply about giving more luxury and efficiency to your village.

I'd also like to add that this game has one of the biggest modding of communities for city builders. Many people turn here to give a fresh twist to the game, and I highly recommend it! Most of the mods tweak aspects of the game's balance, update its models, and add new resources/building. My favorite mods change the models to resemble the architecture of different cultures, like Japan and Morocco.

This game wasn't exactly endless fun for me. But, for the 7 hours players, it's still a great time, and you can get some great bang for your buck when it goes on sale for $5.

138698672.review:
If you keep playing survival games, RTS games, and city builders without finding one that really grabs you, try Banished. The base game is very simple and that simplicity along with just enough mystery in the mechanics already makes it endlessly replayable and complex to master. The music, the realism, and the environments really lend it a miniature fairy garden feel that I love and find engaging. This is the kind of game where if it hits you just right, your first serious play session will extend deep into the night and the next day and eventually you'll find yourself leaving the simulation running for days at a time as the micromanaging becomes macromanaging and your society crawls slowly towards equilibrium.

And thats just the base game, where I've dumped most of my hours. Mods like MegaMod add an astonishing amount of content, and I can see myself putting hundreds more hours in over the years. And that's really the thing about Banished, it's DEEP so you can't jump in every day. I've owned this game for years and only play a few times a year, with each city lasting several tens of hours. But I know that that enjoyment will last for many many more years to come. This is the Elder Scrolls of survival village building games, no competition.

138385644.review:
This game has a lot going for it: 

- It came out in 2014, and was a part of the "First Class" of city/civ builders; a great way to revisit the root of the genre if you're mostly familiar with more modern iterations
- The initial learning curve is figuring out how to best use your starting supplies, and less about how to survival existential threats. You're not putting up with a constant barrage of things like raiders, plagues, or random events at the start of the game. This makes it feel more fair and affords a level of pride you feel in yourself when you solve certain elements of the early game.
- In addition to my previous point, there's an incredibly fast turn around time from starting over to getting through the first few hurdles of the game (the first couple of winters). This means you won't be stuck in a "Try - Die - Repeat" loop any longer than a handful of minutes, 30 at most if you're just learning the UI. Once you get comfy with the UI, you can go from fresh start to second winter in a few minutes, and you can experiment freely with early game strategies
- There's a nice mid game transition, where you can begin experimenting with how to handle initial expansion, what you should do with your increasing population, and what efforts in your village you want to prioritize.

There are some negatives worth noting:
- The UI is dated, somewhat archaic, and visual/information clarity seriously lacks at times.
- AI is very mixed. On one hand, idle villagers whose job don't have any activity (farmers during winter) will automatically take over menial tasks such as moving things to storage and harvesting resources you've marked to be removed via the "Remove Resources" tool. 
- On the other hand... the AI does not handle housing, automatic pathing (in terms of building roads), or "needs prioritization" in a graceful way that you might come to expect from modern games. Foundation comes to mind, with how amazing the villagers self organize with housing, needs, and occupations
- Final note about villager management and AI: While its great the farmers don't waste a ton of time during winter, there comes a time when you have the make a decision... micromanage the living hell out of everyone, or accept inefficiency. Pausing the game, converting your farmers to more productive jobs during the winter, and back to farming during the spring is not a loop many people can put up with for long. When compared to how job overflow and priorities work in a game like Kingdoms and Castles, it yet again shows its age. And, last thing to note, there doesn't appear to be any form of "job proficiency" that the villagers gain in Banished, which not only doesn't punish the behavior of excessive micromanagement in a way that would at least make sense, it practically enforces it as the most optimal way of playing. Your mileage may vary on how this personally affects your enjoyment of the game
- Late game is rather non-existent. It's a matter of scaling and taking up all the available space on the map. Combine this with the fact that there is a repeatable way of surviving the early game nearly 100% of the time (IE: there's not a map seed that might force you to play one way or another - once you can solve the early game, it stays solved), the game essentially converts into a sandbox civilization simulator... a simulator that is vastly inferior to modern options.

So, final verdict: on sale, as a way to revisit the past of this unique and fun genre, I'd absolutely recommend it. It's a classic of the genre and is worth celebrating it for what it is. If you're looking to spend your money on your "next big game" that you want to eat up a hundred hours of your time, I'd recommend looking elsewhere for now.

138142052.review:
Was doing great. The little town of Aviono, 20k food, 78 adults, around 12 children, and 15 years in. When the 16th year came around, it all went to hell. A fire started, burning one of the three storage barns stocked with food. I tried to get my little people to fight the fire with the wells nearby. They failed miserably and the other two barns caught fire, (this is about the time I realized putting all my food storages close together was a mistake).
The fire started to spread to the wooden houses nearby, so I paused the game and looked up how to fight the damn fire. I figured out prioritizing the fire would help, so I did it and it did the trick. After the fire was put out, I checked out the damage. All my food gone and 5-6 houses destroyed. I knew my first priority should be to get my food back up to support my ever growing population of little people.

This is where I realised I had made another mistake. Over 70% of my food was coming from potato farms, and guess what? All of my farms were right next to each other and an infestation started. Farm after farm were getting infected and loosing crops and I had no idea how to stop it. (I'm not one to go back and load and earlier save) So I paused it and looked it up, I couldn't find out how to stop it this time and I let it run it's course. Now the starvation began, and the graveyard began to fill up with little people's grave stones. It was too late to plant crops to get enough food to feed them all, so I basically gave up and watched everyone die a horrible death. I closed my eyes, mourning the loss of the little people that I had led around for so long.

Then...I opened my eyes. I had three people still living! One 19 year old male and one 22 year old mother with her 6 year old male child. I had another chance to fix the broken city and save Aviono. This female was my last hope, unless I could get her with a female child, all was lost. So I set them to work tearing down the now unoccupied houses of the original Aviono, since I was almost completely out of materials. I got them to live close to eachother and waited paitently untill....success! A female child was born.

Life was good again. I set my new couple to tearing down everything not needed for materials and the future growth or Aviono. In the end, I had two stone houses, one of every type of resource production buildings, a town hall, and a cemetery (to remind me of the past mistakes). I got my population back up to 16 little people, and I sat back and sighed with relief. I had saved a town.
Then I realised that the new towns folk were all inbred children from the three survivors....

137805021.review:
One could argue this game started a revolution in the genre. It still holds up because the mechanics are at the core of thousands of titles that have been released since. 

I would suggest Banished to someone just starting with city builders. Figure out what you really like about the genre and go from there.
You like building cities? Cities Skylines.
You like the environment? Farthest Frontier.
You like the mechanics but don't like the grid layout? Foundations.
You like logistics? any Anno title really.
You just want a modern Banished? Settlement Survival.
..on Mars? Surviving Mars.
..on a space ship? Space Haven.
And that's just my library. 

Worth full price unless the aged graphics bother you. Consider grabbing it on sale, though, it's a classic.

"Banished" is a medieval-themed simulation survival and building game with intuitive game mechanics that is easy to understand. However, players must be cautious of the "side effects" that come with rapid population growth in a short period of time.

The achievement objectives in the game are interesting. It is worth noting that players with achievement-oriented goals may not be able to unlock achievements simultaneously if they have installed mods.

《Banished》是一款中世紀背景的模擬生存建造遊戲，其遊戲機制直覺明瞭且沒有過於複雜的天賦樹，非常容易上手。不過人口在短時間過量成長後的副作用也需要玩家小心服用。
遊戲中的成就目標在設計上意外的蠻別出心裁，需要提醒的是，成就取向的玩家在有安裝MOD的狀態下，目前是沒有辦法同時解鎖成就的。

This is my favourite city/village builder. There is so many things going on, children, disease, death, education, entertainment/religion. 
All of the people are named as well, so you can actually watch generations of a family come and go as you are playing, which is pretty cool.
There are some absolutely great mods which add multi level housing, add various resources and products and generally flesh out a lot of the base game mechanics as well. 

The only thing this game really lacks is violence there are zero bandits or bears which would be amazing in some sort of sequel or successor.

This game doesnt hamstring you like so many of the more modern builder games do, if you want to build your pigpen next to a house you can, these people are banished! and any scrap of food/shelter is enough just like real people who are stuggling are not like the need to tick boxes "people" of other games of the genre. 

This freedom breeds creativity so every town can truly be different, instead of having to build optimally or people are sad... and disappear? or prefer to be homeless/hungry if everything isnt perfect, kinda silly.

So much replay value, It can be tricky to manage or at times or more of a chill session depending on your starting conditions/goals.
This game came out in 2014 and still there is nothing as good as Banished.

136936039.review:
My reviews are mainly gameplay focused.

The AI is functional, the game "works";no major gliches, each system/resources are accounted for. The problem is that the player doesn't know.
Being a survival game, resource management is core but the game only gives you vague stats and no proper ways to control.

Say there is a ingame disaster, a fire in your warehouse. You cannot ask your villagers to prioritize in taking care of the danger (so they eat their food whilst on fire. At most, you can order to "prioritize the area" which is very vague. Will your spare builders or the nearest villager interact?), you cannot control which resources to enable/disable so the wood doesn't spread the fire the next time. You can only build a well or near a river, preventing the disaster before it appears. With this gamestyle, the player is incentivized to either consider building everything or pray and get lucky that the wrong kind of disaster does not appear.
And even if you have all the buildings, you will still face issues with a barely functional village you cannot manage because this is a survival game; you're walking on a thin rope. Without ingame knowledge, players lack the knowledge to act and adjust accordingly. You have "Needs" to fulfill, with no way of knowing if it's met efficiently so you cannot prepare for the upcoming year, only that you have a surplus (that can easily disappear by the next season). 

You're basically blindly putting blocks together in the hope that it fits. You're playing a city builder with a disease creeping in and the only way of noticing it is when half of your town died.

136497681.review:
Banished is a city-building simulation game that offers a refreshing and challenging experience for fans of the genre. The game's focus on survival and resource management sets it apart from other city-building games like Sim City 4 and Cities: Skylines. In Banished, players must manage a small group of villagers and guide them to build a thriving community in a harsh and unforgiving environment.

One of the standout features of Banished is its attention to detail. The game's graphics and sound design are simple yet effective, creating a realistic and believable world. The game's mechanics are also well-designed, requiring players to carefully manage resources like food, tools, and building materials. Players must also consider factors like weather, disease, and the needs of their villagers to ensure their survival.

Compared to Sim City 4 and Cities: Skylines, Banished offers a unique and more challenging gameplay experience. While Sim City 4 and Cities: Skylines focus more on building and expanding cities, Banished challenges players to survive and thrive in a harsh wilderness. This adds a new level of depth and complexity to the game, making it a great choice for fans of city-building and survival games alike. Overall, Banished is a enjoyable game that offers a fresh take on the city-building genre.

It is probably of those rare cases of a game that is hard to learn, but there is not much to master.

The game will be very difficult at first, so be ready that you'll fail a lot. But once you figure out how things work, the game becomes easy. The downside is that most likely, once you figure it out, the game will become pretty boring. Still worth buying though.

There is no campaign unfortunately. It's just a city-building / sandbox / survival game. You can consider achievements as a quest list though. It is really fun to get them. Besides, they are no that challenging once you understand everything.

If you liked the base game, there are so many great mods, especially overhaul mods like Colonial Charter, The North and Red Ketchup's. There are also many other smaller mods, including QoL mods like Time is Money or Better fields.

It has quite unique town management mechanics which wasn't like anything else that I have played before (at least, at the moment it was released; there are couple of clones already, though). 
If you're not sure, buy it on sale, it worth trying if you haven't played anything like this before.

135769978.review: Banished is a city-building strategy game that is set in a medieval-themed world where players must manage a group of exiled settlers as they build and expand their own self-sustaining community. The game play of Banished revolves around resource management, city-building, and survival. Players must manage their resources, including food, water, and raw materials, to ensure their settlers' survival. As the settlement grows, players must construct new buildings, manage their population, and expand their resources to keep up with the growing demands of the community. One of the standout features of Banished is its emphasis on realism and attention to detail. The game's mechanics are intricately designed, and the game's world is procedural generated, offering a unique and dynamic experience for each play through. The game's graphics and sound design are also impressive, with detailed environments and atmospheric sound effects that add to the game's immersion. Additionally, Banished has a modding community that adds even more content and features to the game. Mods can range from small tweaks to the game's mechanics to complete overhauls that add new buildings, resources, and game play mechanics. However, one potential downside of Banished is its lack of depth and replay ability. Once players have mastered the game's mechanics, the game can feel repetitive, with little variation in game play from one play through to the next. Additionally, the game's difficulty can be punishing at times, leading to the failure of the player's settlement. In conclusion, Banished is an excellent city-building game with a focus on realism and attention to detail. Its procedural generated world and intricate mechanics offer a unique and dynamic experience for each play through, and its modding community adds even more content and features to the game. While it may lack depth and replay ability, those who enjoy city-building and resource management games will find a rewarding experience in Banished.

135651876.review:
My 700+ hours played on record is my actual play time, not left running in the background hours. 

I have created hundreds of villages and saved countless banee lives. I have built utopias and hellscapes. 

I had to finally stop playing this game (for now) after building a self-sustaining village on an XL map with a population over 6000. I ran out of space for buildings on the map and my fps dropped to 12. I felt bad for my graphics card so I started playing the shit out of Frostpunk instead. 

The trick to building massive villages is literally to build "15 minute cities" side by side. Each suburban area should have its own duplicate amenities so banees don't have to travel as far. Build your forested areas in the CENTRE of these suburbs with foraging buildings on their borders, and resist the temptation to deforest everything. 

Boom, you get a baby boom and well-fed, happy people in a post-scarcity medieval society.

135594482.review:
A peaceful and rather basic city builder, tasking you with managing the survival of a small group of people.

[hr][/hr]
Banished sees you start out with a couple of workers, a couple of resources and the task of constructing a town which will allow your people to survive the seasons. Fundamentally, you’ll have to create housing and establish decent food as well as firewood production to ensure your population will make it through the winter.

Once you managed that, you’ll slowly expand, establishing resource production, clothing and tool manufacturers, schools and more. You’ll have to assign your people to the different jobs becoming available, making sure everything gets done while all basic requirements of your population are met.

There are only a few different resource types, making for basic production chains and very simple building. Additionally, there’s a rather limited number of different buildings types serving only a couple of mechanics you’ll need to keep track of. However, the early game especially features quite a steep difficulty curve, with sparse resources and even sparser work force available to perform all necessary jobs. While this lets up as you establish your town, there are some special events, such as plagues, fires or tornados thrown in from time to time in order to keep you on your toes somewhat.

After building a trading post, the game allows you to collect a variety of produce plants and livestock types from visiting traders. While the plant types especially won’t act much different from the ones you started out with, this at least gives you a bit of a goal once your town is big enough to be stable. Banished also offers Steam Workshop Support, giving you plenty of mods to expand the game’s basic content. I’d also like to mention that I very much enjoyed the game’s soundtrack.

[hr][/hr]
I very much enjoying Banished's focussed gameplay, which kept me hooked for a while in spite, or maybe because of its simplicity.

135134989.review:
Banished, a city building strategy game by developer Shining Rock Software, is one of the most ambitious games of its kind. Unlike other similar city builders, Banished boasts a unique and realistic atmosphere. Set in the middle of a harsh and unforgiving winter, players must use their resourcefulness to create a thriving, cohesive community from a handful of exiled settlers.

The gameplay in Banished is simple yet wholly immersive. Much of the challenge in Banished is in creating a comprehensive strategy for managing your resources and population efficiently, as a limited supply of resources and ever-changing weather conditions throw their fair share of curveballs. At its core, Banished requires the player to make sure that the basic needs of each citizen are taken care of, while also striving to expand their settlement's capabilities and its population.

On a technical level, Banished is simply stunning. The graphics are detailed and full of character, and the game's sound effects and music create an oppressive yet beautiful atmosphere. And while the game's loading times and technical hiccups can occasionally be tiresome, it's ultimately a minor nuisance that can quickly be forgotten in the face of spending time to manage and build one's own city.

In conclusion, Banished is an absolute must-play for any fan of city building sims. With its captivating atmosphere, incredible depth, and engaging gameplay, Banished will captivate any player for hours on end. Highly recommended!

I've read a few reviews of the game before buying and it sounded great: building/management/survival sandbox with no set objectives. I was expecting something like medieval Frostpunk with no story, and that would be fine.

Then a tornado came and killed 95% of my villagers. There is basically nothing you can do about it. No related gameplay mechanics besides the "New Game" button. How fun!.

Sometimes you have to try a bit hard to really get into a game. Others you see clearly after a short time if its worth your time and just go for a refund. This one has a good premise, but it's shallow and not very interesting, unfortunately.

134277569.review:
All things considered, I'd rather be playing Rimworld.

Almost everything Banished does, Rimworld does at least five times better. It's not a perfect analogy, since Banished is sort of pseudo-medieval with no tech advancement, but the broad outline is similar. Only in Banished it's much, much simpler with far fewer details.

In Banished, you build houses, grow crops / hunt / gather food, do some *extremely* basic crafting (generic "tools" from iron and wood, clothes from leather or wool), and do some trading. The game models individual colonists, each of whom has a job. You can't assign jobs to individual colonists, you just specify how many farmers, blacksmiths, fishermen, etc. you want and the game assigns those jobs. Colonists don't have any skills beyond "educated" or "not educated," so any colonist can do any job equally well.

Progression is minimal. There's no research, the main reason you don't assign all the specialists possible on day 1 is that you don't have enough people, and you don't have enough resources to build all the specialty workplaces. "Progression" is 90% just gathering enough rock and iron to build all the workplaces, while maintaining enough farmers. 

Once you've got enough people and resources to build the basic specialists - forester, woodcutter, blacksmith, tailor, school - your colony is stable, and won't change much beyond getting bigger. The main thing is making sure you're producing wood, firewood, tools, coats, and education. This happens in the first few hours of play.

This feels like the bare skeleton of a colony management game, the basic foundation on which you'd build the rest of the game.

134089384.review:
Banished is a fun curiosity

It's a challenging city builder that on it's own isn't that remarkable. But due to the community workshop the game can get pretty wild. The base game in itself is solid with the overall goal being "don't starve or freeze to death", With other community building goals coming after you achieve some semblance of communal stability. (all stability is a lie though and you'll watch in horror as a poor harvest or lack of firewood causes a famine that kills 90% of your city leaving behind a ghost town being watched over by a handful of elderly. They'll whisper "you should have done more" and you'll feel bad on the inside.)

The game is hard but not without difficulty settings. Harder settings really just start you off with less people. The game in it of itself becomes easier and more enjoyable with rapid population growth, division of labor and the ability to form not just a surviving town, but a happy town. 

The game starts you out with a storage barn of limited tools and food, as well as a stock pile of resources to start building houses, farms, hunters lodges, etc. It;s not overly complicated and can be enjoyable. creating a thriving town from 10 outcasts is a good feeling.

There is one more thing to note, this game is tiny. it's literally 50mb and can run on a PC from 1999. This means if you have this game in your library you can install in on any device and wait for that rare itch to develop a city. Before a week ago I haven't touched this game since 2014. But since testing out my Steam Deck this is one of my favorites as it doesn't compete for disk space or drain battery. 

Overall it's a solid 75/100

In short: A simple on the surface town building game where your biggest obstacles are the climate and starvation.

You start off with some peeps and some supplies and have to build your town from scratch. You have to protect your people from the environment and disease, and funnily enough; demographics. Your people tend to die from old age in waves, and that can throw a wrench in things.

It's a relatively early colony game, so your colonists only have the now-standard name/skills/nutrition/health/warmth. It's still fun to follow a person around and see what their day is like though, and sometimes simplicity and clarity of scope is a good thing in a game.

Overall, I'd call this a 7/10 game to play focused only on it, but a 10/10 background game while you're doing something else like watching a movie.

132885033.review:
Banished is a challenging and engaging game that offers players a unique and immersive experience. The game is built around a simple premise, but it is surprisingly complex and difficult to master. Players are tasked with managing a small community of people who have been exiled from their home, and must help them build a new life in a new place.

The game's graphics are simple, but effective, with a clean and functional interface that is easy to navigate. The gameplay is well-designed and offers a good level of challenge, with players needing to manage resources carefully and make tough decisions about how to allocate their limited supplies.

The game's sound design is also well-implemented, with a peaceful and calming soundtrack that is a great fit for the game's relaxing and contemplative gameplay. However, there are a few issues with the game that detract from the overall experience. The game can be quite slow at times, with long stretches of waiting for resources to be gathered and buildings to be constructed.

Additionally, the game can be quite punishing, with one mistake potentially leading to the death of your entire community. This can lead to a frustrating experience, especially for newcomers to the genre. The game's lack of tutorial or guidance can also be a barrier to entry, with players needing to rely on trial and error to figure out the game's mechanics.

Overall, Banished is a unique and engaging game that is worth checking out for fans of the genre. While it has its flaws, the game's challenge and complexity make for a rewarding experience for those who are willing to put in the effort. I would give it a score of 6/10.

131876096.review:
Fair warning: This game is unfinished. Once you get to a certain point, your town will stagnate no matter what, usually followed by a flurry of deaths that may or may not cause a cascade of other deaths as you struggle to fill the holes left by the people who just died. This is neither a feature nor a bug, but a result of the game not having an end-state and the player not having the tools necessary to stop such events. With extremely careful planning, you can reach an equilibrium where such cascades are unlikely, but as far as I'm aware there's no way to prevent them entirely.

That said, the game is great *before* you reach that point. It goes on sale regularly as well, so if you have 5 bucks lying around and you see the price has been slashed, I'd highly recommend it.

131790952.review:
Bought this as everybody seemed to praise it in other games review and I wish I didn't; it really feels like an unfinished game.
The big issue with this game is that after a few hours there's nothing more to do. It starts at a very challenging pace, when you have to do some micromanagement to optimise the usage of the scarce resources and especially workers. But as the time progresses, that part goes away and if you're not a chaser of games badges you'll get bored, very quickly. There are no missions or campaigns or research or politics. Economy is incredibly basic, with just a few buildings and secondary products (literally: no secondary product requires non-primary ones). Those buildings mechanics are sometimes very annoying: for example, you can't set the working area for them, and often that's a very large one that will cover a considerable amount of a smaller map. Quarry areas can't be reused after they finish their stone supply. You get tons of different crops and trees to grow; some will adapt better to the weather or give food slightly earlier, but overall there's not a huge difference from growing one or another. The existence of other towns is only present thanks to commerce. Commerce itself is very meh - can order some stuff (not all of it) overpaying it, or try to rely on what merchants bring - which seems random. Merchant boats also arrive rarely and at totally random times, they often won't accept many items for exchange and it's hard to tailor your economy for commerce. It's also not possible to convert anything into "money". My advice: do not buy unless you're very bored or it's in heavy discount.

131697940.review:
Banished is a game that promises a lot but fails to deliver in many areas.
The graphics are simplistic and unimpressive, with most of the game taking place in a bland and uninteresting environment.
The gameplay is often unbalanced, with players spending most of the time gathering resources with little to do with them.
The game's lack of proper tutorial and guidance can make it difficult for new players to understand the game mechanics.
The game's multiplayer aspect is often plagued with cheaters and hackers.
The game's lack of variety in tasks and environments makes it feel repetitive after a while.
The game's developers have not done much to address the game's issues and update the game.
Overall, I would not recommend Banished to anyone, there are far better games in the same genre that offer a more satisfying and polished experience.

This game has been out for 8 years and it still has not lost its charm.  Most other games after 8 years end up in the trash dumpster.  Not this one.  

Probably the most amazing thing about this game is that it was developed and published by 1 person.  I have played many other city sims that with an army of developers were not able to pull off what this guy has done by himself.

The game is great.  The music is relaxing.  It is as chill as it can get for a city sim.

To make this great game into something awesome only requires installing 1 mod.  The MegaMod takes hundreds of other mods and bundles them all up into an easy to install package.  No need for some complicated tool.  Just copy into a folder and BAM! game is now in awesome mode.  The amount of map choices along with the amount of buildings, industries, etc., makes this somewhat simple game into an overwhelming masterpiece.  

I cannot say enough good things about this game, other than if you like city sims, but are fed up with things like SimCity and City Skylines, look no further than this little gem.

I do recommend this game, but I'm not sure that I really like it at all.  It's very easy, there's not a lot of options that really allow you to make it look unique, and the lack of any kind of endgame without high levels of customisation means that it's very much a one and done experience.
I start by mapping out the initial area that I want my boarding house, town hall, market and trading post to be in without building them.  Once those dirt roads are in then it's a simple matter of hunter, fisher, gatherer, 4 fields and boarding house.  Click 10x speed and go.  After this it's really just a matter of waiting for the people to reproduce enough so that you can throw in more buildings.  There's no challenge here, my hearts never dipped and nothing really happened.  It was very much a build, wait and see kind of experience.  Now it is nice looking, well designed and the systems are all fine, so I can't say it's a bad game.  It's just incredibly dull and very much a mindless experience.

[h1]A Thoughtful and Challenging City-Building Strategy Game[/h1]

READ FULL REVIEW [url=https://videogamerate.com/game/banished]HERE[/url]

Banished is a city-building strategy game that tasks players with building and managing a small group of settlers as they attempt to establish a new colony in a harsh, unforgiving wilderness. The game is set in a medieval fantasy world and features a range of mechanics that require careful planning and resource management in order to thrive.

One of the standout features of Banished is its focus on realism and simulation. The game does a great job of recreating the challenges and realities of life in a small, isolated community, and players must carefully consider everything from food production and resource management to healthcare and education in order to ensure the survival and prosperity of their colony.

The game's weather system is particularly noteworthy, as it can have a significant impact on the well-being of your settlers. Severe storms, for example, can disrupt food production and make it difficult for settlers to go about their daily tasks, while harsh winters can lead to shortages of warmth and shelter. Players must therefore be proactive in preparing for such events and ensuring that their colony is well-equipped to weather the storms.

Another strength of Banished is its depth and replayability. The game features a range of different resources, buildings, and structures that can be unlocked and utilized as your colony grows, and players are given a good deal of freedom in how they choose to expand and develop their settlement. The game also includes a number of different scenarios that present unique challenges and objectives, which helps to keep things fresh and interesting even after multiple play-throughs.

One potential drawback of Banished is its difficulty. The game can be quite challenging, particularly for players who are new to city-building games or who are unfamiliar with its mechanics. The game does a good job of easing players into its systems, but it can still be overwhelming at times, particularly when your colony is hit by unexpected disasters or other unforeseen events.
 
Fun Factor: 85
Banished is a genuinely enjoyable game to play, particularly for fans of city-building or strategy games. Its focus on realism and simulation adds a level of depth and immersion that helps to keep things interesting, and the wide range of resources and structures available for players to unlock and utilize adds a good deal of replay value.

Visual & Sound Quality: 75
The graphics in Banished are fairly basic but are effective in conveying the game's medieval fantasy setting. The game's interface is clear and easy to navigate, and the various buildings and structures are well-detailed and look good on screen. The soundtrack is fairly minimal but is fitting for the game's setting and atmosphere.

Replayability: 90
Banished has a great deal of replay value thanks to its wide range of resources, buildings, and structures that can be unlocked and utilized as your colony grows. The game also includes a number of different scenarios that present unique challenges and objectives, which helps to keep things fresh and interesting even after multiple play-throughs.

Level of Challenge: 80
Banished can be quite challenging, particularly for players who are new to city-building games or who are unfamiliar with its mechanics. The game does a good job of easing players into its systems, but it can still be overwhelming at times, particularly when your colony is hit by unexpected disasters or other unforeseen events. That being said, the game's challenging nature is part of its appeal, and players who are willing to invest the time and effort to learn its systems will be richly rewarded with a satisfying and rewarding gaming experience. 

Overall, Banished is a thoughtful and challenging city-building strategy game that offers a great deal of depth and replayability. Its focus on realism and simulation, combined with its wide range of resources and structures, make it a great choice for players who are looking for a more immersive and challenging gaming experience. While it may be a bit daunting for newcomers, those who are willing to invest the time and effort to learn its systems will be richly rewarded with a satisfying and rewarding gaming experience.

128685963.review:
As of this writing, I have invested over 560 hours into this game. There is so much nuance that goes into managing a fully functional economy that despite being well over 500 hours of playtime, I still find myself learning the mechanics on a more intimate level.

From growing crops and mining, to manufacturing, and ultimately trade, there is no limit to how far you can micromanage your small fiefdom. There are several mods(like MegaMod, for example) that make this game infinitely more enjoyable than it already is in it's "vanilla" form. I would strongly suggest that be your first mod if you're a new player, just take care in your "stack order" if you do choose to play with mods. Some mods will interfere with others if they aren't stacked in their correct order, and you can usually find these recommendations in the mod descriptions.

If you wish for a medieval SimCity/Cities Skylines that caters to OCD levels of gameplay and city management, this is your game. Yes, at times it can be nerve-wracking(ie; population die-offs), but I find it to be rewarding enough to keep coming back.

128565307.review:
This game is finished, and no longer appears to be receiving updates. It's fine though, because it's really no kidding totally finished, and thus no updates are needed. 

It's a hobbyist fishbowl, but the fish die REALLY REALLY easily. 

Except the fish are people and the bowl is your town. It's not quite an idle game, but it is a game that to be successful, you have to sit back and just watch it for a while. So you set your stuff up, and then you watch how it plays out. Tweak a little bit. Tweak a little bit. Watch some more. The bigger your town is, the more time you spend just watching. AND YET, it is super addictive. My hours do not reflect active playing time -- I used to leave the game running while doing other stuff a LOT.

Also be aware that the challenge is in survival, not building. There's really only so town-creative you can get with the mechanics as they are and your bannies (the lil people) are super super fragile. Expect to spend your first chunk of hours starving over and over and over again. 

Modding community is a++.

Its a 5/10 colony survival city builder.  Its sort of hard until you figure out your just balancing food and population.

The UI is super basic.  You cant do a lot of basic function things.  Cant move a building once built.  Cant prioritize building multiple projects.  Cant order laborers to clear over distribute ect.

Game is missing a lot of simple tools like map creators, lots and lots of missing settings for a new game.  This hurts replayability.

Game is missing any form of progression in game.  No unlocks though building special buildings, no upgrades, no modifications. You get everything right from the start, and its all one layer deep, meaning it does what the building says and nothing more.  This really hurts replayability..

This game got some hype long ago, but feels like a game that is an early access game with bare basic functionality, and it came out in 2014.  Has this game even had patches since then?

Even the game world is super bare basic.  Just a temperate forest always.  Some hills or more hills,  harsh or mild climate.   Always rivers and at least one lake.  Always the same couple resources, no wild card or curve ball resource to make things interesting.

Game had a great foundation but hasnt seemed to evolve in any way since its launch.  Pick it up on sale.  I feel ive seen it all in 15hrs and theres nothing new to see.

Banished - простенькая, но очень захватывающая игра о создании поселения группой людей.
Вам предстоит с нуля основать деревушку и заботиться о жителях, обеспечивая их всем необходимым: едой, домами, дровами, одеждой и прочим.
Несмотря на свою кажущуюся простоту, на деле игра оказывается очень сложной. Она требует невероятного чувства внутреннего баланса: вы должны грамотно распределить людей по профессиям, использовать ограниченные ресурсы, оптимально расположить здания на карте (от этого зависит эффективность рабочих, свободное время, успех охоты и сбора урожая), и самое сложное - следить за демографической ситуацией. Если построить слишком много домов, поселенцы будут жить по отдельности, состарятся и умрут.
Главное не забыть построить колодец , иначе пожар не потушить .

Информация для тех, кто желает видеть игру на русском:

- Перейти на вкладку Installed Mods и у появившегося мода поставь крестик возле Enabled .

125283994.review:
So I'm saying, yes I recommend this game but with a caveat. Grab yourself a handful of mods (trust me). Whether it's for vastly expanded gameplay and building options or ease of use, it makes the game substantially better. Now here's where this game has a MAJOR issue. Resource distribution (food primarily). You have storage warehouses, barns, etc and then you have marketplaces. All of which citizens will pick from to get their necessities. So here's my gripe (a) you can spend literal HOURS building up a great settlement. I personally got as high as 100 citizens, but with that comes the obvious growing demand for food, heating, etc. If you make ONE miss-step you'd better be ready for a DRASTIC die off. I had tons of food throughout but as I focused on trying to build new things I've been dying to do since this is a city builder I noticed an actual decline in my food stock. So I reacted accordingly but since things like orchards take a long time to payoff the issue got continually worse (b) when someone is looking for (let's say food in this example) they'll walk toward a storage or market place and if the food isn't there that second they walk all the way back. Mind you food could be delivered seconds later or the market down the road could have some but they'll walk off and die instead (c) with the amount of storage / market places you really need to handle the expanding neighborhoods you create; and keep in mind that foresters, hunters, gatherers, herb collectors really need to be placed on the outskirts in order to maximize efficiency, it leaves you searching all these different places if you're looking for specific building resources you might need. The ultimate result for me at the moment is almost 200 hours into the game on 2 different attempts. Most recently I went from 100 citizens down to 56 in a single year! Mind you I shut down a ton of non essential buildings and focused entirely on food producers for that entire year. You simply cannot correct without absolutely demolishing your work. So now I have this city that had so much exciting things starting to happen, but it's absolutely worthless. Figure something out because the average player is not going to want to run through trial and error and waste so many hours to figure out how to get the ultimate result they desire.

All that said though, I'd still recommend this to the avid city builder because if you can deal with the extremely frustrating and time consuming failures; this game has a lot of fun offerings and a lot of long-term playability. Just again; make sure you mod. What I've got more than doubles the experience.
