125137941.review:
This is a fine example of a city builder done right.

Rather than relying on spectacle, Banished simply gives you cold, hard gameplay. You start off with a small group of people and you are tasked with building a town and insuring their survival. It’s not the easiest thing, but once you get the hang of it, it’s a smooth ride.
Unless you’ve made the mistake of turning on disasters, the game is a pleasant little experience. Most of its playtime is just you expanding the village until you eventually encompass the whole map. The game is not a complete breeze, as you do actually need to thing economically when it comes to managing limited resources, villager mortality and the alike. Quite fitting in a city builder.

Extra props go to the coding of the villagers, as they will actually automatically move to houses that are nearest to their workplaces and other similar stuff like that. This is a feature that is actually quite lacking in other, bigger city-builder/manager games.

[u]Now, the game does have a few cons. [/u]
For starters, you very quickly go through the content. Once your through, all that’s left is to expand and grow the settlement.
There are a few extremely rare bugs. Or so I’m told, I haven’t experienced anything past a single mentally ill villager that started doing a run around the world once.
The disasters are quite unfun, as they just spawn a tornado that kills 90% of your town and undoes hours’ worth of progress without you being able to do anything about it.

[u]Fortunately, most of its cons can be easily addressed. [/u]
Your getting bored of the base game? There’s mod support.
Had some bugs? I don’t believe you.
Don’t like disasters? You can turn them off and they don’t affect achievements.

Overall, this is a game for people who are looking for a distraction while watching something on another monitor. This is the kind of game you get to idle your way through while still getting some level of challenge. It is also more of a simulator than it is a game.
Some people dislike it for its simplicity. I myself, like it exactly because it’s a grounded village simulator.
Id even go so far as to call it a gem, though be it a gem that you might want to get at a discount, as ~$19 is a bit steep for some people, considering there isn’t a massive amount of variety in some departments.

I wish I had found this gem sooner. Here I am in 2022 telling anyone who reads this that a game from 2014 is just as good (if not better) than anything published today. I'm at 125 hours played, and I can see myself playing this for another few hundred hours.

Of course the wonderfully talented modding community has made the game much more enjoyable, but I highly recommend starting off by going back to basics, and playing the game vanilla/unmodded to begin with.  If you like a challenge then vanilla/unmodded Banished will give you just that - a challenge. The challenge is tremendous fun!  Yes, even losing all of your citizens to starvation, tornadoes etc is entertaining, as it encourages you to always try to do better.

I'm a 'beauty builder' and the vanilla game just doesn't have enough to satisfy this for me. This is why mods are in my opinion vital, if like me you like to decorate, and bring a sense of realism to the game.

I like to try to get the achievements in games, and I found a few of the achievements quite a challenge, but if you search the forums/reddit someone always has some great advice to help you along.

124094890.review:
Pros:
- Graphics are wonderful 
- Easy to learn mechanics (even without tutorial)
- Mods are offered through the game itself (and are great!)
- Very fun and relaxing!

Cons:
- Tutorials are boring
- No terraforming and weirdly shaped maps
- Unable to move buildings (have to destroy them, then rebuild in a new location)
- If on 10x speed farmers are unable to harvest entire field in time for winter
- Unclear how much food population needs (See below)
- Achievements are difficult to obtain (I can't get a population over 100 without half of them dying off)

Overall I enjoy the game. It has it's faults, but it's fairly easy to overlook them and just enjoy it. The one thing I hope the developer patches (or maybe someone can make a mod for) is the food consumption rate. I can go from 5,000 units of food one year, to half of my population starving to death the next year, with no changes in food production and minimal births. It's making it very difficult to grow my population, and is rather frustrating at times. Especially as a player that loves farming mechanics, and 4/5 of my population is farmers, I don't think that should happen every few game years. :/

124084417.review:
This is like a precursor to games like Frostpunk. You need to play in a certain way for you to proceed. What that way is.... well that's like a mystery and you must solve it through process of elimination.

I was going great guns on my first game - then realised my population was all old and dying. I did some research and it turns out... no wait for this... I didn't have enough houses. And apparently my little digital citizens don't like to procreate in busy in houses. They need to see available housing stock to go breeding.

This is not only just so secretive in its behaviour - the game gives zero indication of population housing issues - but also just quite frankly disobeys everything we've learnt about history where in poorer times people do share homes and yes they do procreate like crazy. Look at a census some time!

You can then get a tornado just because which wipes out your town, lolz.

Or my latest game where it's snowy every two days and food won't grow and now they'll starve.

It wouldn't be so bad if the game were a bit more transparent, but it almost likes to be secretive and go "Surprise!"

It also has questionable pathfinding/resource management. I need to build a mine. It needs stone. So logically you build a little storage area for stone, then mine stone nearby so it goes to build the mine nearby. Logical yeah? No, they'll take the stone back to the town centre nowhere near the mine.

People management is very fiddly. And there's no logic - for example you can't say if you're not building something, go do other labourer stuff. If your production facility is maxed out - go do building. They will sit and do nothing.

It is the sort of game where you go "one more go..." to see if you can master it. And I'm sure I will. But that doesn't make it a well designed game.

Edit: I did do one more go. Quite a few times.  It's one of those games like a puzzle that it does make you want to scratch an itch. But it's only because the game is chaos, at the end of the day And you are trying to bring order from chaos. It has complexity, but without proper control so it make you flick switches to see if it can all work.

But at the end of the day those switches are fickle. You can have HALF your population on food production but they will starve. You can literally have thousands of units of food and you can see they are at a market metres away from a 'starving person' and they don't eat.

I mean, a farmer will die of starvation in a field of food. It says it all.

Play Anno 1404 if you want complex supply chains. And importantly EVOLVING supply chains. Banished is food or die, that's the only balance once you're past a few years of gameplay.

So, Medieval Indie SimCity. I dig it.

The first couple of games were super frustrating for me, once people start breaking their tools, starvation and low firewood follows, they begin to die and an evil downward spiral starts and everyone dies, hahaha!

But you got to learn from your mistakes and do research like how to create forest production nodes, the importance of well placed housing and storage and how marketplaces are vital for distribution, the ART of building effective roads to increase efficiency and how to balance education so you have enough laborers but planning for educated population for the future. *chef kiss*

Getting 100% achievements is relatively quick, except for the 200 years one, you could get most of them in under a week, a couple of days if you play daily a lot. Once you get the hang of the game, achievements are very easy too.

Graphics and sound design for the game are fine, this game is pretty old (2014?) but I feel it still holds up today (2022), The tutorials help but the wiki and people who wrote tips for the game really saved me. 

I really liked Banished and I hoped it had more interesting achievements like: Survive 10 tornadoes or quell 100 fires, survive a famine, etc, more disaster related ones but it still was a very fun few days.

Banished gets a rating of 34 starving hunter-gatherers out of 40 forest fires.

123170960.review:
This is a tough game to rate as clearly a lot of care, consideration and work was and is being put into it... In the end it just isn't for me however and I don't think it is for a lot of people:
Banished is a small scale development sim, in which your modes of control are basically limited to city planning and the indirect assignment of professions. Accordingly I found myself not doing much more than dialing up and down the number of workers in the defined fields of work, then waiting and watching on fast forward. This forms a periodic and soon repetitive cycle as most of the time there's not much more to react to other than the change of  seasons. In my oppinion the immersion is lessened further by a very thechy UI that reminds me of a piece of business software rather than a video game: Windows, tabs, tons of buttons and even a "get help online" style wiki.
As a result, Banished acts and feels much less like an actual game and rather, well, a high level of abstraction economy simulation. This means there are some interesting and maybe even profound insights to the mechanisms of growth and trade to be found here. At least for me that just doesn't make it a video game yet though: I'm sorely missing the "fun" aspect of that category here.

I'd recommend to save often to undo said mistakes/inattention or to prevent a game ending natural disaster (A tornado you can't recover from, a fire you weren't able to extinguish, etc.). 121930139.review:
10/10 
IT'S ADDICTIVE
Firstly, it's just so cathartic. The soft music, the simple mechanics... A pleasure to play. Gives me a Settlers vibe. 
It will punish you for not paying attention. This game needs micro management, but this is a good thing, as it keeps you hooked. This is not SimCity where you can get everything running smoothly and then walk away for an hour and come back to endless weatlh. No, this game requires you to strategically build houses at staggered intervals in order to balance the breeding population. Too many houses? Everyone splits up and no one has kids. Not enough? They won't raise kids in their parents house, and everyone kind of dies off. 
Contrary to some reviews, I view this game as a complete product. It's a finished game, though due to it's punishing nature, I've read some complaints, People suggesting the mechanics are broken. I disagree. The game needs to be the way that it is, in order to actually pose a challenge.  Give it a go

121856486.review:
If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

121099254.review:
This game is a wonderful baseline for any city simulator. In fact, it has written the book on how to do it and many more current games are based on it. You have to manage several key resources quickly, and continuously for you towns people to survive. You have to manage the number of houses for them to continue having children for the next generation. And personally I love the style of the entire game.

cons: personally, there are a few things that irk me in the game. You cannot earn achievements with any mod enabled. I suppose this makes sense so people cannot cheat, but very annoying as 90% of mods are cosmetics. There is a plethera of cosmetic and minor change mods that make this game from baseline gameplay to absolutely amazing. I've seen colonial styles, japanese styles, even viking remodels of all the game ellements. There are game changing mods such as removing coal from houses forcing them to continue relying on firewood that is easily replaced/regrown.

I also personally dislike when games like this make things so terribly un-renewable. regardless of your oppinion on the subject, not being able to build on the old quarry ground, and the mine running dry in only 2 years is just insane to me and not at all realistic. 

I still will play for a long time on this game, trying to achieve all those complicated achievements (so far about 200h and 0 of them earned- LOL), as well as just enjoying building dif styles of towns with a bunch of mods making it easier and more artsy to play. 

I would still definately recommend buying this game, though its older, for anyone who enjoys city sims or town layout building games. This old gem ain't going anywhere for a long time :)

120765102.review:
Banished is quite fun through the early and mid-game with charming graphics and very immersive, atmospheric sound design. Unfortunately, after that it all falls apart. You very rapidly reach the mid-game (as there is no end-game) and that's your lot. A dozen or so buildings, a hundred or so colonists, then the winters come and go with blinding regularity and no promise of any further progression. The game looks great but feels unfinished and, considering it's last update was a beta patch over 7 years ago, that makes sense. It was a cute idea that never ended up being fully developed and became abandoned. As much as I dislike developers now charging us for the privilege of playing their games when they're at their worst, I get that is how the industry works these days. What I absolutely will not support is charging full price for an unfinished game. What Banished amounts to is a free demo of a game that was never made. If it were ten dollars or less I might be more lenient towards it but, for 20 dollars, I expect more than a demo. 
Get it on sale if you absolutely must play a nicely atmospheric city-builder but there are better and more cost-efficient options out there.

120531090.review:
maybe I need to play it more, but I just don't want to.


The first tutorial is very informative.  The other three try to cram in too much information and do not offer a lot of opportunity to actually practice what is being taught.


It's difficult to tell what is "wrong" with this game, but what I am suspecting is the major "wrong" with it is information.  Mainly, there's a severe lack of clear information at any given moment.


The game tells you how to gather resources and build buildings and the like in order to get started and to survive.  But there's no central information "hub" by which you can monitor everything clearly.  As well, you don't get clear information with regards to what SPECIFICALLY is needed.


For example, you need stockpiles of stone, iron, and wood to build most things.  The game doesn't explicitly tell you what actually is iron, but you can figure it out on your own that it's the smaller, darker rocks among the stones.  The game also doesn't tell you that you need a supply of iron tools and hide clothing because the tools break from use over time, and your townspeople are apparently incapable of making fires so they freeze to death very easily.


Are you bringing in enough food with just a fisherman's hut?  No one seems to be starving, but just to be sure, you adds some farmland.  Is this enough?  You don't know, but now you've got 6 people working on food production instead of 3 and you only have 10 people who can work.  So you can either have a surplus of food and a severe labor shortage, or take a risk that you might only need 2 people fishing to support the other 8 while they gather rocks and grubs and flowers.  There's nothing in the game that keeps track of this sort of information for you, and since this is a game and not real life, you cannot actually go visit the store and figure out what "30 food" actually means.  30 pounds?  30 handfuls of corn?  30 fishsticks?  


How many adult human people can "30 food" feed and for how long?  Nothing in the game clues you in in any way, so you're essentially left permanently guessing how many workers is enough in a certain job place, and how much "income" of food or raw materials is satisfactory.  And if you guess wrong, your settlement of 12 people is cut down to 7 as the other half have suddenly starved to death or frozen to death because you didn't think to emphasize one particular job over another, such as building a Tailor shop instead of a Blacksmith, or a Trading post instead of an extra Farm, but then the food ran out before traders could arrive.


A whole lot of the gameplay mechanics seem to have been either offhandedly touched upon in the tutorials or are otherwise left there as a "try this out and see" type situation.  Add to that the very tiny and unintuitive UI and the need to micromanage every single person's job and it's extremely easy to end up being overly fixated on one specific thing and lose focus of other things.

120139119.review:
For such an important game--it seems like a good half of new city builders are "Banished-likes"--there's really not that much to Banished.  But what's there is so solid that it's easy to see why it has been so successful and influential.

Banished is a game that throws out the core tenets of SimCity-style city builders, wherein your focus is on building infrastructure and laying down zones.  Instead, Banished focuses on micromanaging a small number of citizens to get them to collect and produce the resources that allow them to survive while directly constructing the buildings they will use.

The only real infrastructure is roads, and even those are more or less optional.  The technology level is decidedly primitive, something around low-medieval, and most buildings are focused on various aspects of survival.

As such, this is really more of a "village builder" than a "city builder", although if you keep at it you can eventually spread out over a large area and end up with hundreds or even thousands of citizens.

The core gameplay loop feels great.  You're going to cycle through building things to provide food, housing, and firewood, plus a smattering of secondary needs to keep your citizens healthy and happy and make them work more efficiently.  In the meantime, you'll have to carefully manage what jobs your citizens have, like Farmer or Woodcutter or Blacksmith, via a small spreadsheet window.  Sometimes people will die, and you'll have to rearrange your spreadsheet if you don't have somebody ready to take up their tasks.  It's pretty tricky balancing all these different things in the early going, especially if you don't have a good grasp of the systems yet.

Just figuring out all of those systems and getting a sustainable town running with a few dozen people will probably consume at least a few hours of your time, but it's satisfying when you start to get it all running, and even more satisfying when it becomes a well-oiled machine.

The problem with Banished, if there is one, comes in after that point.  At a certain point (it took me starting over once and playing around 9 or 10 hours) there will be nothing left to do except repeat the same core gameplay loop.  Banished does not have a tech tree; every building is unlocked from the beginning, provided you have enough resources and can sustain using the resources and workers to run it.  The total number of buildings is fairly small, and only one of them allows you to upgrade it in any way (from a wooden house to a stone house).  So really, the only thing left to do at that point is to continue to make your city bigger and bigger.  There's not any further progression.

This is where it becomes obvious that Banished is a very small indie game.  My understanding is it was a labor of love by a single developer, and as such a developer myself, I understand how hard it can be to make even something relatively small like this.  And it's great for what it is, just don't go into it with the expectation that it has a huge amount of depth and progression to keep you engaged.

As for the audio and visuals, they are fine.  Nothing here is going to blow you away (although the weather effects and seasons are pretty cool), and it can be a bit hard to tell some of the buildings apart since they all use the same basic color palette and similar architecture.  But everything is consistent and polished nothing looks or sounds bad, and what more can you ask from a solo developer?

In short, this is absolutely a game worth buying, especially on sale.  But I'll bet most people would get enough fun out of it even at full price.  Just make sure you go in with the right expectations.  This is a small, intimate village builder made by a small indie, and with that in mind, it's fantastic.

119873898.review:
This game has no end game and its not that fun to keep playing once youve got everything working because all youre doing is making your own life more complicated in doing so to the point where things get out of hand really quickly.

Once you get to about 100 population, youve already got everything going and all there is to do is do more of it by expanding and repeating everything.

This game creates situations where dozens of hours of your effort can fall apart so fast and theres nothing you can do to stop it and you just have to watch everyone in your town die due to a small miscalculation you made 20 minutes ago.

You basically have to master the game by restarting new save after new save after messing things up because inevitably youll have failed miserably.  And you have to make new towns over and over until you learn to fit your play style within the extremely limited parameters that the game forces you to play within to be able to not fail.

Not only that, you can make 5000 correct decisions and be an efficiency expert, but you do one thing wrong like accept an unusually large amount of nomads or split more than one animal farm off at once to expand, and youre done. Theres just no coming back to it once the snowball effect hits.

Theres an absolute snowball situation where when a few people die, it sucks off your laborers and then theres no laborers to move things out of your mines/quarries and so you cant build more houses or other buildings if you dont have backup supplies, and that can prevent population growth and in the end, can cause the whole labor structure to fall out of balance and then everyone just starts dying of starvation.

Also, it would be nice if the terrain didnt dictate so many things about where I build.  Placing certain items is way too unnecessarily sensitive and in the end, causes me to lose the game due to not being able to build where I need to in weird areas, and making it hard to move things around easily after mines and quarries shut down and major labor forces have to migrate quickly.  After a mine/quarry goes out, theres just 15 people living in an area that no longer serves any purpose and now they have to walk 5x as far to get to their job, creating unnecessary problems.

Just let us bulldoze quarries/mines, it is not fun in any way that it leaves giant gaps in the map.

Great idea for a game, just extremely frustrating how it actually plays out due to how shit hits the fan out of nowhere and youre done. You just have to quit after watching your 100th death despite you doing everything you can.  The game is like trying to steer a boat away from a surprise hazard, you can make a sudden correction but the change wont happen until its too late and thats it, youre fate is sealed.

Not fun when your fate is sealed in a game.  Its more fun when you feel like you have more control and can do things that can fix things, but when you can see the outcome being inevitable, thats an uninstall from me and a negative review for wasting my time and money on what was supposed to be a fun game.

I know there are mods, but I paid for the game and had hoped it to be fun out of the "box", not expecting part of my payment to be mods fixing what should be fixed without, especially since I understand nobody gets paid that mods.

This review could be changed in the future if an end game and quality of life issues are considered, but I know how things go and seems like not a lot has changed in the future.

Game is good for 20-30 hours at least for me, until I started really feeling like im stuck playing in a strict process, and not feeling like im playing anymore, and instead just working.

119579283.review:
[h1]Positives[/h1]
+ Old, colonial style wood and stone buildings is a great aesthetic and era for this type of game.

+ Has a good balance between micro- and macro-management.

+ You can manage worker allocation from multiple menus, which helps keep the game flowing and eliminates a lot of big menu navigation.

+ Game speed control is a nice QOL feature; nice that the game respects your time and lets you speed up the simulation. Obviously playing at 10x speed might make you miss something, like a merchant or villager needs, so use at your discretion.

+ Even though it's challenging and you might restart a lot, the gameplay loop is actually relaxing, especially playing on slower speeds. It's a chill time listening to the bustle of workers hammering and sawing away, and watching the little villagers go about their simple lives.


[h1]Negatives[/h1]
- Some disasters, like tornados, can completely ruin your game. This adds a good challenge but is too skewed in my opinion. If a single tornado comes through and your villagers happen to be grouped up, game over. It wouldn't be so bad if there were more ways to protect against disasters or if villagers would notice weather changes beforehand and take shelter.

- Non-renewable resources such as stone and iron end up needing to be traded from the merchant boats that come to your town every now and then. This is the most efficient way of getting bulk amounts of these crucial materials later on. Unfortunately, that means a lot of your trade power goes toward basic supplies, which is not very fun or interesting.

- Needs more building variety or tech-tree system that allows for upgrades to existing buildings. As it stands, you can build everything the game offers right off the start if you really want to. It focuses on efficiencies and breadth expansion rather than depth.


[h1]Summary[/h1]
Base game completed:  N/A
DLC completed:  N/A
Rating:  7 / 10 - Good

Ok, so having spent a fair few hours on this game, I actually don't really have a whole lot to say about it. 

I would say that I would recommend this game to others, if they don't have a lot of experience with city builders. I kind of view this game as a pretty standard, normal, average city builder. 

I actually appreciate the simplicity of it. The game doesn't have any real gimmicks to it that (later) additions to the genre would add. The colonists aren't beavers, robots, in prehistoric times, in the post-apocalypse, or anything else. You're just building a village in the woods, and simply need to get food, wood, and water, and build some houses, connected by roads. 

Play the game if you want to get into the genre for the cheap, and understand the basics of it. You should maybe stay away from the game if you're a veteran, and you're looking for a special city-builder you've never played before, though you should maybe play it if you're just looking for a no muss, no fuss resource management experience.

118210570.review:
So, I'm usually pretty bad a city-building games, but I do love them. I love to design with the challenge of also being functional, even if I always end up bankrupting my town or starving everyone out. I'm bad, but I have fun trying.

This game feels like a good simplification of games like Cities: Skylines or the Tycoon franchise. Mostly, I am thinking about the layout of my town, the aesthetic of my roads and how far out I want the treeline.

And while I slowly build out my town and try to expand, I inevitably hit a point where food sources are struggling. So I will try to build another way to produce food, but too late. And within a minute, my whole town starved to death. But I had fun trying. And it's never too daunting to start over.

The scale is pretty small, but I enjoy that. I am not worried about schedules and prioritizing work automation like Rimworld. I am never obsessing over traffic like Cities: Skylines. I am never falling behind because I let time pass without min-maxing the progression of my base (Starcraft). I just slowly expand, adjust to the needs of my growing population, and try to balance the basic needs with my desire to expand.

Fun, simple, easy to pick up and speed through for a session.

117409727.review:
Gameplay is decent, but this game is the least stable example of programming I've ever seen.  The game crashes when you load a save file (while already in a game), about 40% of the time when you open the map (how? how did somebody screw up THIS badly?), and finally - just about whenever it feels like. And when the game freezes, you can't alt-tab to anything else.  All you can do is restart your computer.  This happens multiple times per day.  And this game has had these problems for YEARS.  This game is abandoned and won't get fixed.  Buy a better city game.  And don't even get me started on how you can literally have 70% of your ENTIRE POPULATION on farms and catching fish and picking fruit, and yet you'll still starve. 

Oh, and there's no way to prioritise things.  You know Oxygen Not Included? You know how you can ramp up the priority of something and watch your little dupes build or operate or dig it?  Nope.  You have something that CLAIMS to be something that ups the priority of any task in its square, but I've hammered that over buildings and resources already flagged to be built/collected, and watched my 10 labourers ignore it for almost an entire in-game year.  Good luck building farms while you're starving, watching your food storage number go down FAST while your stupid villagers do anything BUT save themselves.  This game is STUPID when it comes to food.  Like, real stupid.  Food production is 100% your priority, and not even having the majority of your population devoted to food will be enough to save you.

Because a famine is inevitable.  Your villagers all eat food, and if you expand too fast they'll grow beyond their means to provide for themselves.  Like me, you could have 70% (SEVENTY PERCENT) of your entire village toiling away under the hot summer sun on farms and fisheries and orchards, and I guarantee you this somehow still won't be enough.  And then a fire hits and your entire village burns down despite you building WELLS every 10 feet.  And then you get hit by a plague that infects the entire village because one villager glitched out and wandered around town infecting everyone instead of going to the hospital.  And then 2/3 of the town dies because the game doesn't warn you that if a lot of people are BORN around the same time, they'll DIE around the same time - and you created a population bubble by sinfully building 3 houses one year instead of the usual 1 or 2.  And god help you when nomads show up and push that bubble to the breaking point.  Hope you have literally 50,000 units of food stored, because you're going to need them.  For reference: you start the game with just 1 or 2 thousand units of food, and that lasts you long enough to get a food source and set up some houses.  I cannot emphasise enough how obsessed this game is with food and how easy it is to reach a tipping point where not even OVER SEVENTY PERCENT of your entire population devoted to food production will fix.

And bear in mind: this is AFTER I downloaded a mod that makes fields twice as productive.  How stupid do you think your vanilla game is going to be?

This game is a huge mess.  I have no idea how this game costs as much as Rimworld or other (better) sim games.  You are being ROBBED.  Do NOT buy this game unless it's 75% off.

3.5/10

117237267.review:
Banished is a very good game of village management. I like it very much but it is a simple game. You don't develop technologies (which does mean it is a bad thing) and you are not competing with other settlements (there is no invasions nor wars). It is, then, a very simple game mechanics wise but it is very difficult, especially early game. 

All these characteristics makes Banished relaxing and enjoyable. It is more like an AFK game (for me or my playstyle) than a strategic game because after you settle in the land and learn how the mechanics works, you are pretty much safe against mistakes and it is only a matter of hoarding resources to expand the village. 

The worse thing about Banished is that the game doesn’t tell you how things work (like a 7x7 farm is the best way to optimize a 1-person farm), although it doesn’t spoil the enjoyment, since we live in a world where information is right there, so a quick search fort community tutorial got me all the information a needed.  

If you are looking for a simple village management, I recommend Banished, it is not an expansive game and it delivers what it proposes to do. It is a good way to get started in the genre. On the other hand, if you are looking for a more complex game, you should look elsewhere (Rim World or Gnomoria i.e.)

117036219.review:
I've enjoyed a lot of hours playing Banished, and still do.  I've added some features from the creators - different crops and trees and a few different buildings; but I turned off Disasters since I don't like interruptions when I'm planning and growing my town.  I prefer starting new towns; once I get all the buildings up and the population and food sources stable, I usually stop and create another town.  

The game has a lot of variety and you must keep reassigning your people to tasks as it cycles through each year - harvest fruit in early Summer, go to the Hunting lodge in Autumn, plant crops and gather foods in Spring and Summer.  People don't like to travel far from their homes, especially in winter when they get cold and hungry; so wait to build structures further away during Summer and Fall.  Keep an eye on the Firewood and Logs, and after the first 5 years always have one unassigned worker available to replace others who die off.  

Workers only bear children up to a certain age, then they stop having more; so don't build all the housing at one time - two or three new houses every year keeps children and students in the pipeline to take over when adults age out.  

If your first town is in a bad location, start building away from it and eventually demo it - you can put a pasture or quarry in its place later.

Recommended for people who like strategy, resource management and an easy pace (and no blasters or explosions!)

116419131.review:
Hello everyone, I am the exiled G.E.M.Simov, a very capable civil engineer who also has a PhD in resource management and city planning. Today, I will tell you about Banished.

Simple review details - I rank games on an out of 10 basis, granting up to 3 points in 3 categories, as well as a last, single point from my own self, depending on my experience with it.

Gameplay

Banished is a GAME. What kind of game, you may ask? Well, it is a… A medieval city management game that has no ending. You, the player, are presented with a start menu. You, the player, click on the button that initiates the game, and, after a few selections - pertaining to size and difficulty - the game begins.

A big area, square, is relegated for the city. And… That’s everything. From that point onward, the player, you, must give out commands to their citizens, who can take up a multitude of jobs, from being a simple laborer to being a teacher, or a leather-worker, or a doctor. However, there comes the first issue.

The citizens are, much like real people, retarded. They have some kind of AI, but it is exclusively Artificial, and not intelligent, not one bit. They will use roads, if there are roads, so as to move faster, however, their approach to anything will not attempt to be optimal. Give them the command to gather resources from a certain area? They will travel to the furthest possible point of the designated area, and gather the resources from that location, instead of first gathering resources from the nearest area.

God, whether existent or not, forbid that you, the player, decide to designate ANOTHER area for resource exploitation, before the first area is fully drained. The idiotic citizens of the city, no matter how well educated, will behave like lemmings. As in, they will do stupid things, and everything will fall apart.

Ignoring the stupidity of the citizens and the utter lack of control over them that you, the player, have, Banished is a neat game about city planning and management. The starting make-up of the city depends on the difficulty, but, unless you are a casual, 5 minute per day player, you ought to get on with the most difficult start ever - a cart with barely any food and 4 families.

Direct your, the player’s, citizens to gather resources. Tell them where to build what. Observe as they do so, and then find yourself wondering… Why? Only to then find out that the answer is simple. If not, then we die from the cold, or we are just unhappy and work far less efficiently, or we become so unhealthy we neither work well, nor do we live all that long. Leather-working? For clothing, to keep people warm while they’re working. Smithing? For tools, to exponentially increase the productivity of the people. Houses? For housing, to exponentially increase the production of people.

Everything in this game is reminiscent of that other game - Factorio - and it is almost all about efficiency. Build up a city, in accordance with what your citizens require - be it food, religion, or even alcohol - but do it in an efficient way, otherwise you will starve, even though you have food. You will find yourself being cold, even though you have firewood - the issue will be that it is simply too far, and the idiots, that are your, the player’s, citizens, cannot understand that they need to go on a brisk, one hour walk, to reach the barn, and then they need to lug around twenty kilos of firewood, for another brisk, one hour walk, so as to keep themselves warm in the winter.

This game is great in the sense that it appears splendidly well suited for the so-called practice of 'map-painting', or, rather, simply the activity of city planning. In a sense, the player, knowing that there will be zero efficiency unless they, themselves, set out to create that efficiency, is urged, by the game, to get to work. The simplest means of describing this is that, as soon as the player gets to playing, they can start laying down the foundations of their city. In fact, if the player has enough knowledge of the game, they can just jump at the opportunity and get to planning out the entire city. The existence of a button that allows the player to postpone building structures, yet still place them on the map, is really pleasant.

It is one of the great things, I say, about Banished, this ability to just create a layout. Actual, proper planning, all the while the game is paused, and nothing is actually happening. The issue is, that… Well, until the player can get to that point, they need to spend a long, LONG time playing the game in the usual manner - which involves just slapping things down as they become necessary and being reactive in your, the player's, approach to playing the game, waiting for your food or tools or clothes or health or happiness to take a hit, which is when you, the player, will figure out that you need to place the appropriate building.

It is fun for the first… Thirty minutes, to maybe an hour, but then it becomes a little tedious. The player sees the growth of their city, and it is a very gradual growth, but it is one nonetheless. It is satisfying, knowing that, at the beginning, there was just a cart of stuff, and now there's a whole square, but… Well, this need for optimization bothers the player. After all, our human brains are manufactured in such a manner that they seek the most optimal approach to everything, as that means we utilize less energy, and the brain is made to conserve energy… So the player feels as though stuff COULD be more efficient, but, well, the means of making it more efficient really feels as though it's the exact opposite of satisfying, and much less, efficient. 

1/3

Read the rest of this review (as Steam limits how long they can be) on my website:
https://gemsimov.com/game-reviews/f/banished---a-review?blogcategory=Game+Reviews

116292237.review:
It is very difficult to micro-manage in this game.  You can learn tricks like deconstructing a house to kick two of the same gender people living in it out.  But you shouldn't need to do this, the game should know that you want a male and a female living together to produce children, especially if you are on Adam & Eve start.  But it doesn't know.  You have to know the trick and see it by clicking on each house individually, sooner the better.
  It is also difficult to min-max in this game.  ie how big should you make your crop field?  Who fucking knows?  Sometimes one colonist can cover a pretty big field by him/herself, but when does it jump to 2 colonists max work?  What size field?  Want to know?  You have to look it up to figure it out because you don't want to have a guy plant like 1 tree and the other guy plant 49 trees (or produce way too much food and waste work time.)  
  Stupid things can happen and it will ruin you sometimes.  For example, my educated gatherer starting colonist ate poison berries one day and just died.  Like what...?  Did they commit suicide, like that makes absolutely no sense.  How can you be educated and then go do that dude.  I like when bad things happen that also make sense.  Random fire?  fine it doesn't really give any reason, you don't do anything to cause it to happen but alright.  Do fires happen more often at higher weather temperatures or when you build wooden houses instead of stone?  I don't know lol it's probably just random, nothing specifies it so you have to just assume.  
  There is no taking direct control of your colonists which is a real bummer for me.  The best you can do is force heighten the priority on the construction of anything such as a road or building.  But that's it.  And even that is super janky.  You can't que things up unless you know what you're doing.  No way to see builder que.  Builders will sometimes prioritize GATHERING RESOURCES instead of BUILDING even if it shows they are working on the construction of a building (3/3 builders) so they basically are invisible labourers.  You must figure out when this happens to fix it ASAP especially during the creation of a new colony, as not getting buildings up fast can ruin a colony easily.  And that's a pretty stupid way to have a pilgrimage fail.  Imagine the report.  The builders felt like gathering wood instead of making the fishing dock so it looks like they all immediately starved to death as soon as they ran out of potatoes sir.  They had the resources...  Why didn't they just finish construction?  
After 152 hours I still don't really know how the que system works.  It seems that builders will gather instead of build if you que the removal of resources after the que of the build.  And that's just bad.  It shouldn't be happening and it happens all of the time.  I would let it slide if they were uneducated but it doesn't matter.
  If you play with Colonial Charter mod (the dev's mod that they released) your game probably will randomly crash.  Leave it open too long and it will crash unlike any other steam game I have in my library.  Hate to do this but compare it to Rimworld.  I can play over 300+ mods made by random people and if you have some sense about it then it will work fine with 0 crashes.  This game is so janky that you can't even get it to run right with 1 mod active that the DEVS MADE which is ridiculous.  I don't ever have problems with games crashing so I am positive that it's the game and not my pc.
  I know I have lots of hours on this game.  It can be fun but I would not recommend this game to people.  It's like you have to figure out how the game works to have fun with it.  You have to know that eating only one kind of food is unhealthy in this game.  You have to know how to get leather to make hides.  The animal pens were always exponentially stupid and a complete waste of a colonist's time. which is sad bc the animals look really cool.  You're 20x better off making one gatherer  than having a pig pen or chicken coop.  Dev mod makes things extremely unbalanced and that is kind of an important thing.  Basically if you build the wrong building or make your farm too big or pen too small or just some stupid thing it can make your colony fail in such an underwhelming way.  If you make a problem there is usually no way to redeem yourself except save scumming.  You fucked up.  Learn this dumb game mechanic to not fuck up and die next time.  
And yea I have made lots of prospering villages but never can really decide what their specialty is.  I have to pick from pretty similar starts that get boring after a while and it's always make a trading place and you get what you get.  I feel like the game doesn't let me do what I want to do really.  small example is that you can only grow specific trees in certain climates.  So which climates are applicable to which trees?????  No way of knowing.  
I want to like and recommend this game but it's just not good enough.  Go play rimworld it's fun as hell.

[h1]  Great Little City Builder [/h1]

Almost anybody who like city building will like this one. 
The game has a bit of learning curve, but once you got it down it's very fun.

The game has a lot of options for difficulty, terrain, etc, so you can adjust it to your preferences.
It does however have a poor "late game", as it feels like the only thing you can do once you have a stable economy is expand the population and resource gathering until you cover the map. There is no scientific development, tall buildings, "wonders" etc. It's all survival, which keeps it simple but also makes it boring as the time goes by.
 
After hitting that point you can start over with adjusted settings to give yourself a challenge, or you can mod the game!

Overall fun, simple, little city builder.
